Alachua County Map History of Alachua County Communities Live Work Play Municipalities Gainesville Alachua Archer Hawthorne High Springs Lacrosse Micanopy Newberry/Jonesville Waldo Real Estate Apartments Commercial Real Estate Know Your Neighbor Education School Map K-12 Private Magnets Career and Tech Online University of Florida UF Online Santa Fe College: A Global Focus Health Care Public Health Services Hospitals & Emergency Care UF Health Specialty Clinics & Services Non-Emergency Care Business Business Community Biotechnology Greater Gainesville Chamber Innovation Incubators & Startups Culture Food Scene Breweries & Distilleries Arts Sports and Recreation Weekend Getaways Lifestyle & Wellness Music Scene Things To Do Pet Services Non-Profit Getting Settled Moving Quick Tips Emergency Contact Numbers Transportation Voter Information & Engagement Gator Sports LATEST NEWS Live Work Play Hundreds of Greater Gainesville residents can meet many of their needs within their neighborhoods â€“ in live, work and play communities. These developments go back to the 1970s, when Haile Village Center was created in the middle of Haile Plantation, a 1,700-acre development with a variety of housing styles located west of Tower Road. Today, Haile Village Center offers dining, medical and professional offices, specialty shops and hosts events, including a farmerâ€™s market on Saturday mornings. The areaâ€™s most recent live, work and play community is the 160-acre Celebration Pointe, located along I-75, north of Archer Road. Celebration Pointe has developed over the past decade both as a lifestyle center for local folks and a regional destination for shopping that includes a Bass Pro Shops as well as Nike, Tommy Hilfiger and Skechers outlet stores. The development is centered around The Promenade, a pedestrian area with venues, including Kilwins and The Keys Grill & Piano Bar. Spurrierâ€™s Gridiron Grille, named after former University of Florida football coach and Heisman Trophy winner Steve Spurrier will open in 2021. Celebration Pointe includes the Hotel Indigo. The second phase of the communityâ€™s Main Street project is developing. The expansion includes more retail space, 100 luxury apartments and offices. Dave & Busterâ€™s, Prime & Pearl restaurant and Sensei Asian Bistro are part of the growth. Celebration Pointe is leasing a 220-unit luxury apartment project known as City Place. The VUE, Celebration Pointeâ€™s townhome development, is also growing. A third live, work and play community is the Town of Tioga, a neo-traditional development on Newberry Road that incorporates a variety of housing styles on small lots reminiscent of historic small towns. The Town of Tioga includes the Tioga Town Center, a shopping, dining, office and apartment complex. The town center hosts events, such an art show and the Tioga Car Show. It features a Gainesville Health and Fitness branch, shopping such as Down to Earth Boutique, Lang Jewelers and Complete Home Boutique, and offices for other businesses including AEI Affiliated Engineers,Weyerhaeuser, and UF Health Pediatrics. Hankin Group, the town centerâ€™s owner, is adding 144 luxury apartments to its existing group of apartments there, and it is building 15,000 square feet of retail space. Tioga Evolves The Town of Tioga was considered to be ahead of its time when it began selling homes in 1997, developer Luis Diaz said. Luis and his father, Migel, were considered daring in placing homes closely together like they were in early American villages and in their native country of Venezuela â€“ as an alternative to building on larger suburban lots. In developing the property, which had been a farm, they walked the woods over and over in an effort to maximize the common green space. â€œWe were determined to preserve the old tree lines,â€ Luis Diaz said. Acceptance of the Town of Tioga concept has grown over time, and the community has grown to 420 homes â€“ with more on the way. â€œPeople who donâ€™t live here park their cars and take a walk, and couples use Tioga as a background for engagement photos. Itâ€™s a great compliment,â€ Diaz said. The merchants in Tioga Town Center find it a good place to do business. Blue Highway is in its 11th year in the community. â€œWe could not have chosen a better location for our business,â€ said Layla Rufino, who owns the business with her husband, Frank. â€œOur guests enjoy coming here for the quality food, drink and shopping available.â€ Bich Nguyen, the owner of Enso: A Healthier Nail Boutique, said Tioga Town Center has exceeded his expectations. â€œThere isnâ€™t a better spot we could have opened the first non-toxic nail salon in Greater Gainesville,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s wonderful for us to feel accepted and welcomed from clients and other merchants alike from day one.â€ Jason Hurst, the owner of Maple Street Biscuit Company, also commented on the town center. â€œMy wife and I had a vision to open a family-friendly, community-based location, and Tioga Town Center fit that description perfectly,â€ he said. â€œWe have a wonderful extended family, and we attribute it to the warm atmosphere of being a part of the Tioga Town Center.â€ Cheryl Carroll, Regional Asset Manager for Hankin Group who owns and manages the Tioga Town Center and The Flats, also lives and works at the Town Center. â€œThe healthy and diverse mixture of retail, medical, business, and restaurants brings so much value to living at The Flats,â€ she said. â€œMy family and I love living in a community where we have everything we need, all within steps of our home.â€ Celebration Pointe Experience â€œI love to live my life here,â€ said Samantha Howe. â€œItâ€™s a hub that brings a lot of people together.â€ The 2017 University of Florida graduate works at Infotech, a software and consulting company serving the transportation infrastructure industry that relocated its headquarters to Celebration Pointe in 2017. Howe, who lives in a nearby apartment, regularly takes Luna, her German shepherd mix dog to the Celebration Pointe dog park. Howe enjoys lunch, dinner and happy hour at the restaurants and bars along Celebration Pointeâ€™s pedestrian-only Main Street. Haile Village Skip and Lynda Everitt have a perfect combination of lifestyles in the Hickory Walk section of Haile Plantation. They live on the Haile golf course while being able to walk to Haile Village Center for dining and neighborhood events. â€œSince I started playing golf at 13, I have wanted to live on a golf course, but I like a compact neighborhood that is relatively self-contained,â€ Skip said. â€œThese two aspects of our situation go together well.â€ Everitt and his wife, Lynda, moved into Haile in 1993, and they have seen the massive development evolve over the years, adding two Publix supermarkets and many homes. Haile Village Center is better than ever. The Everitts enjoy eating at Limerock Road, That Bar and Table and Haile Village Bistro. â€œWe see a whole lot of people we know when we go to them,â€ Skip said. They look forward to Haile Oktoberfest and the holiday lights each year. Lynda and Skip founded the Twilight Round Golf Tournament, an event held annually from 2003 to 2008 that honored Lyndaâ€™s father, a victim of Alzheimerâ€™s Disease. â€œWe got to know a lot of people through that,â€ Skip said. The couple values Hickory Walksâ€™ diversity in terms of ages, professions, interests and cultures. â€œWe have graduate students, people with young kids and people our age,â€ Skip said. â€œPeople mingle in our three common areas as well as gathering for the holidays in these neighborly spaces. Weâ€™ve never been happier.â€ Contact Us CostelloCM. Gainesville, FL (352) 281-2072 (352) 372-5957 scott@costellocm.com Subscribe to receive GUIDE news & articles in your inbox! Cookies are small pieces of text saved by websites to your computer. Cookies are how your computer remembers things youâ€™ve already done on the internet and are an important part of making modern websites work properly. Because cookies may contain information about your browsing habits, some people prefer to turn them off entirely. However, turning off cookies can prevent websites from working the way you expect. Essential cookies These cookies are critical to the functioning of this website and cannot be disabled through this control panel. They donâ€™t contain any information about your identity. They can be disabled through your browser, but doing so could cause some parts of this website to stop working. WordPress wordpress_, wp- Always enabled Analytics cookies These cookies collect information on visitors to our website to help us understand how well our website is working and how to improve it. No vendors are present in this group. Targeting cookies These cookies collect information on your browsing habits to help our advertising partners show you more relevant ads. No vendors are present in this group. Social media cookies These cookies help social media sites understand your likes and dislikes so they can show you more relevant content. They also make it easier to share contents from other websites such as ours to your social media profiles. No vendors are present in this group. Gainesville, 
                                    
                                                                            FL                                    
                                                                            32608 352-378-0721 Get Directions View Website Overview Haile Village Bistro brings flavors from across the world into Gainesville. The kitchen is open 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. Sunday through Thursday and 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Breakfast is served daily 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. Ask your server about tasty desserts. The Queens Arms Pub is a British-style pub located next door and is open 11 a.m. â€“ 10 p.m. Sunday through Thursday, and open until midnight on Friday and Saturday. The first Saturday of every month features a tea party with finger sandwiches, quiches, scones and a variety of pastries. The last Sunday of every month features the Persian Night Buffet with an array of authentic Persian food from 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. CHECK OUT WEEKLY TRAVEL INSPIRATION Explore What's Good. By utilizing advanced cleaning techniques and high-quality products, the facility ensures that every vehicle receives a thorough cleaning tailored to its specific needs. In addition to exceptional service, the car wash prides itself on a welcoming atmosphere, where staff are trained to provide friendly and informative assistance. Customers can expect not only a clean car but also a pleasant experience that encourages them to return. Our Range of Services At Laurel Canyon Car Wash, we offer a comprehensive suite of services designed to cater to all vehicle care needs. From express washes that provide a quick clean to full-service hand washes and detailed interior cleaning, there is something for every customer. Each service is performed by trained professionals who understand the intricacies of vehicle care. For instance, our interior detailing includes vacuuming, shampooing carpets, and wiping down surfaces to ensure every inch of your vehicle is spotless. Customer Testimonials Feedback from our customers plays a crucial role in shaping the services we offer. Many clients have praised Laurel Canyon Car Wash for its efficiency, attention to detail, and the overall quality of service they receive. For example, one customer highlighted how impressed they were with the full-service wash, noting that their vehicle looked brand new after the treatment. These testimonials not only reflect our commitment to excellence but also provide potential customers with confidence in choosing our services. Contact Us for More Information If you have any questions or need further information about our services, feel free to reach out to us. Our team is ready to assist you with any inquiries, ensuring that you have all the information needed to make an informed decision about your vehicle care. You can contact us via email at info@laurelcanyoncarwash.com or call us at +1 (818) 495 - 9322. We also encourage you to visit us at our location in North Hollywood, where our staff can provide personalized assistance and recommendations.

Manager of Haile Village restaurants arrested for embezzling almost $68k from owner - Alachua Chronicle Skip to content Menu Home Categories Business Community organizations Crime Cultural events Education Elections Fires Health Letters to the editor Library Local government Opinion Public notices State government Traffic incidents Jail Booking Logs Obituaries Events Search Advertising About Us Contact Us Home Crime Manager of Haile Village restaurants arrested for embezzling almost $68k from owner Manager of Haile Village restaurants arrested for embezzling almost $68k from owner February 21, 2024 Staff report GAINESVILLE, Fla. â€“ Shannon Jennifer Moccia, 44, was arrested yesterday and charged with grand theft and 127 other felonies after allegedly embezzling almost $68,000 while she was employed as manager of two Haile Village restaurants. The owner of Haile Village Bistro and the Queenâ€™s Arm Pub contacted Alachua County Sheriffâ€™s Office (ASO) last July to report that he believed Moccia, the general manager of both restaurants, was stealing from him. He said the agreement between him and Moccia was that Moccia and her husband would run the businesses and pay their expenses, paying the owner a percentage of the profits and splitting the remaining profits. Moccia was reportedly fired six days before the owner contacted ASO. The owner reported that the business bank account was linked to his personal account for overdraft protection, and after traveling overseas for several months in 2022, he noticed that about $40,000 had been transfered from his personal account to the business account, indicating that the business had lost that much money over that period. He told the investigator that over $150,000 was transferred out of his personal account to cover overdrafts in the business account between September 2022 and August 2023. The owner told the investigator that he knows many of the regular customers, and when he spoke to them, he learned that many of his regular customers had stopped patronizing the business after Moccia was hired as general manager. The owner told the investigator that he investigated the financial records of the business and learned that Moccia had been using the businessâ€™s credit card to purchase personal items and had also written 64 checks to herself. He said that when he confronted Moccia about this, she said the money was all used to operate the business, but she reportedly had no records or receipts to prove that. The personal items purchased on the businessâ€™s credit card totaled about $2,600, and the checks written to Moccia totaled about $29,000. The owner told the investigator that Moccia was authorized to withdraw cash from the bank account to replace cash in the register and pay tips to the servers, but the amounts of cash were calculated to be about $36,000 more than was needed. Post Miranda, Moccia reportedly admitted that she had purchased items on the businessâ€™s credit card, had written checks to herself, and had withdrawn cash from the business, but she said she was authorized to do those things by the owner; she said she did not understsand how she could have done anything wrong because she had â€œpermissionâ€ to use the businessâ€™s funds as her own. She reportedly said that she â€œblendedâ€ her personal finances with the businessâ€™s finances and that she wrote checks to herself as reimbursement for items she purchased for the business; however, she said she had no receipts to prove that. Moccia reportedly said she reimbursed the business for any funds she used for personal expenses, but the investigator wrote that the bank statements show that that is â€œno discernible recordâ€ of money moving from her personal account back to the business account. When the investigator asked Moccia why the amounts she paid out for tips were increasing during a period when the restaurants were failing to the point that one restaurant closed, she reportedly could not answer. She also reportedly changed her statement to say she had kept receipts, but they were in the safe at the business. The investigator concluded that Moccia stole almost $68,000 from the business. Moccia has been charged with grand theft over $20,000, fraudulently obtaining property over $50,000, fraudulent use of a credit card, 64 counts of writing fraudulent checks, and 61 counts of using a two-way communications device to commit a felony for using a mobile applicaton to deposit 61 of the checks. Moccia has no criminal history; Judge Thomas Jaworski set bail at $100 per count, for a total of $12,800. Articles about arrests are based on reports from law enforcement agencies. The charges listed are taken from the arrest report and/or court records and are only accusations. All suspects are innocent until proven guilty in a court of law.
